formula: a(n) = Sum_{i=0..n} 3^(n-i)*B(i)*binomial(n,i) where B(n) = Bell numbers A000110(n). - _Fred Lunnon_, Aug 04 2007a(n) = exp(-1)*sum(k=>0, (k+3)^(n)/k!) - _Gerald McGarvey_, Jun 03 2004. May be rewritten as a(n)=sum(k^n*(k-1)*(k-2)/k!,k=3..infinity)/exp(1), which is a Dobinski-type relation for this sequence. - _Karol A. Penson_, Aug 18 2006Define f_1(x),f_2(x),... such that f_1(x)=x^2*e^x, f_{n+1}(x)=diff(x*f_n(x),x), for n=2,3,.... Then a(n-1)=e^{-1}*f_n(1). - _Milan Janjic_, May 30 2008Let A be the upper Hessenberg matrix of order n defined by: A[i,i-1]=-1, A[i,j]=binomial(j-1,i-1), (i<=j), and A[i,j]=0 otherwise. Then, for n>=1, a(n)=(-1)^(n)charpoly(A,-3). - _Milan Janjic_, Jul 08 2010a(n) = sum(A143495(n+3,k),k=3..n+3),n>=0. - _Wolfdieter Lang_, Sep 29 2011G.f.: 1/U(0) where U(k)= 1 - x*(k+4) - x^2*(k+1)/U(k+1) ; (continued fraction, 1-step). - _Sergei N.
